messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] kodogu translation
messages.msgSnippet: ... Supposing this is not gimei for some reason, I guess the kao would help tell them apart? There is an overall feeling of newness to this as well, so I would
messages.messageBody:
<jggilbert@...> writes:

> Darcy,
> The first one is Hiroyuki with a kao. There are several makers listed
> with that name.

Supposing this is not gimei for some reason, I guess the kao would help
tell them apart? There is an overall feeling of newness to this as well,
so I would think that the maker would be working in the 1800s.

> The second is Nara Toshi (Naga?) followed by a kao. I'm not seeing
> the second character on the left very well, but if you're seeing it as
> the other "toshi," that kanji can also be read Naga and there are a
> number of makers signing that way including the Nara Toshinaga of
> sansaku fame.

Robertson character 187 is the one, most definitely and beyond a doubt
in person. I couldn't get it to stand out very well on the scan, I've
been sorting out various things since coming back from Japan so I didn't
put a lot of effort into getting a good clear one.

Reading it as naga is news to me though, thanks for the tip, I will do
some digging. I don't have much in the way of documentation for kodogu,
but I saw something for a Toshinaga, none for Hiroyuki though.

Thanks very much!

- darcy

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] kodogu translation
messages.msgSnippet: Darcy, The first one is Hiroyuki with a kao.  There are several makers listed with that name. The second is Nara Toshi (Naga?) followed by a kao.  I m not
messages.messageBody:
Darcy,
The first one is Hiroyuki with a kao. There are several makers listed with that name.

The second is Nara Toshi (Naga?) followed by a kao. I'm not seeing the second character on the left very well, but if you're seeing it as the other "toshi," that kanji can also be read Naga and there are a number of makers signing that way including the Nara Toshinaga of sansaku fame.

Jim
I bought a couple lower end pieces while in Japan because I liked the
composition. Now I'm screwing around with the mei.

The first is a tsuba that I read as Hiro Yuki and the third character
escapes me.

The second I was told was Nara Toshichi... when I look up those
characters for the mei though on the left, I get Toshi, and an alternate
Toshi. The last is a cao?

Can someone shed some light on this for me?


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: kodogu translation
messages.msgSnippet: I bought a couple lower end pieces while in Japan because I liked the composition. Now I m screwing around with the mei. The first is a tsuba that I read as
messages.messageBody:
I bought a couple lower end pieces while in Japan because I liked the
composition. Now I'm screwing around with the mei.

The first is a tsuba that I read as Hiro Yuki and the third character
escapes me.

The second I was told was Nara Toshichi... when I look up those
characters for the mei though on the left, I get Toshi, and an alternate
Toshi. The last is a cao?

Can someone shed some light on this for me?


----------



----------


The signatures didn't mean too much for me because as I said, they were
purchased for their nice composition and I would like to use them in
koshirae but I am interested in learning a bit more if possible.

Thanks,

- darcy
